docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline.main: Thursday Reading: An App To Help You Find Better Lightbulbs

docs.abstract: An app can help you find energy-efficient light bulbs, the economic impact of college graduates moving back home, apps to help the Thanksgiving chef and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
docs.snippet: An app can help you find energy-efficient light bulbs, the economic impact of college graduates moving back home, apps to help the Thanksgiving chef and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

docs.abstract: As the Republican presidential candidates begin to turn their attention to the airwaves, two strategies are emerging: attack your rivals or attack the president.
docs.snippet: As the Republican presidential candidates begin to turn their attention to the airwaves, two strategies are emerging: attack your rivals or attack the president.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the Republican presidential candidates begin to turn their attention to the airwaves in the final six weeks before voting begins, two strategies are starting to become clear.
docs.abstract: As the Republican presidential candidates begin to turn their attention to the airwaves, two strategies are emerging: attack your rivals or attack the president.
docs.snippet: As the Republican presidential candidates begin to turn their attention to the airwaves, two strategies are emerging: attack your rivals or attack the president.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some companies are starting to penalize employees who smoke or are obese by raising their health insurance costs.

headline.seo: Smokers Penalized With Health Insurance Premiums

docs.abstract: Some companies are starting to penalize employees who smoke or are obese by raising their health insurance costs; policies that impose financial penalties on employees have doubled in the last two years to 19 percent of 248 major American employers surveyed.
docs.snippet: Some companies are starting to penalize employees who smoke or are obese by raising their health insurance costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Young Americans who can afford to move out have decided to wait until getting on more solid footing, and their prudence is depriving the economy of a lot of potential activity.

headline.seo: As Graduates Move Back Home, Economy Feels the Pain
headline.main: As New Graduates Return to Nest, Economy Also Feels the Pain
headline.print_headline: As New Graduates Return to Nest, Economy Also Feels the Pain

docs.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of young Americans are choosing to live in their parents' homes rather than moving out on their own, even if they can afford to, and their prudence is depriving the economy of a lot of potential activity; by choosing to wait until they have more financial stability, these young Americans are, in a sense, making it more difficult for economic conditions to improve enough to ensure that they have financial stability.
docs.snippet: Young Americans who can afford to move out have decided to wait until getting on more solid footing, and their prudence is depriving the economy of a lot of potential activity.

docs.lead_paragraph: Cuttino Mobley, who was acquired in a trade in November 2008, never played a game for the Knicks after team doctors said he had a potentially fatal heart disease.

headline.seo: Ex-N.B.A. Player Sues Knicks Over Medical Issue
headline.main: Former Player Sues Knicks Over Medical Issue
headline.print_headline: Former Player Sues Knicks Over Medical Issue

docs.abstract: Cuttino Mobley, whose NBA career ended in 2008 because of concerns over a heart condition, is suing Madison Square Garden, claiming that New York Knicks forced him to retire as a cost-saving measure.
docs.snippet: Cuttino Mobley, who was acquired in a trade in November 2008, never played a game for the Knicks after team doctors said he had a potentially fatal heart disease.

docs.lead_paragraph: A health policy expert says the health care law is reasonable, serves the national interest and should be upheld by the Supreme Court. Readers are invited to respond.

headline.main: Invitation to a Dialogue: The Health Care Law
headline.print_headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: The Health Care Law

docs.snippet: A health policy expert says the health care law is reasonable, serves the national interest and should be upheld by the Supreme Court. Readers are invited to respond.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.abstract: Chronically ill patients, and how we care for them, are the key to cutting the cost of health care.
docs.snippet: Chronically ill patients, and how we care for them, are the key to cutting the cost of health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: On a typical night in the emergency room, a patient shows up short of breath, suffering from emphysema or heart failure or maybe both, as well as diabetes and high blood pressure. Doctors and nurses administer inhalers to ease his breathing and diuretics to take off excess fluid, and admit him to the hospital. Over the next few days, interns and residents furiously adjust his medications and fix his diet. He is discharged with a stack of prescriptions. A week or two later, chances are good he'll be right back in the emergency room.
docs.abstract: Chronically ill patients, and how we care for them, are the key to cutting the cost of health care.
docs.snippet: Chronically ill patients, and how we care for them, are the key to cutting the cost of health care.
